did.abstract: This collection contains various typed and handwritten notes and news clippings on Brooklyn history compiled by Brooklyn resident Ruth D. Cruikshank (b. 1892) and organized by subject matter, as well as materials related to the Decker family of Brooklyn.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The folder of original "History notes" is restricted due to its fragile condition. The provided photocopies should be used instead.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged into folders by subject matter.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Reuben S. Decker (1830-1911) was partners with Hamilton Weed in the Capitoline Grounds, which were located on Decker's land, once the estate of the prominent Lefferts family of Brooklyn. One of Decker's daughters was Laura Cruikshank, who may have been Ruth D. Cruikshank's mother.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to the fragile nature of the originals, researchers should use the phocopied "History notes" whenever possible.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Ruth D. Cruikshank papers, 1977.429, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Originally minimally processed to the collection level, this collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in November 2023. At that time, news clippings were photocopied and the originals discarded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains various typed and handwritten notes and news clippings on Brooklyn history compiled by Brooklyn resident Ruth D. Cruikshank (b. 1892) and organized by subject matter. Subjects include banks, mayors, the military, transportation, recreation, prominent Brooklyn citizens and organizations, the Capitoline Grounds on Bedford Avenue, the neighborhood of East New York, and the East Reformed Presbyterian Church, among others. Also included are materials relating to Reuben S. and Sarah A. Decker. Items pertaining to the Decker family include a journal, legal papers from a dispute between the Decker and Brevoort families, receipts, tax bills, and certificates. The collection spans the period 1863 to 1947.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics in alphabetical order: Academy of Music, Advertisements, Autograph album, Banks, Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn Heights, Brooklyn Institute, Brooklyn Theatre victims at Greenwood, Buildings, Columbia Heights, Coney Island, Draft Riots, East River ice, Fires, Friends (Society of), Friends Cemetery, Gas Lighting, Greenwood Cemetery, Irishtown, Judges, Manhattan Beach, Mayors, Monuments, Monument to Lafayette, Orchards, Otton family, Plymouth [Church], Politicians, Ponds, Pratt Institute, Pumps, Revolutionary War, Rollerskating, Sanitary Fair, Schools, Singers, St. John's Church (Fort Hamilton), Streets, Telephones, Temperance, Theatres, Transportation, Waterfront, Williamsburg, Yacht Clubs and Yachting. The subject topics are followed by individuals listed by surname: Abbott, Dr. Lyman; Beecher, Henry Ward; Conway, Lillian; Cragin, Mrs. E.S.; Fancher, Mollie; Kidd, Captain; MacFarland, Daniel; McLean, Andrew; MacMonnies, Frederick; Mosher, Dr. Eliza; Storrs, Rev. Richard Salter; Stranahan, J.S.T.; Talmage, T. De Witt.
